lines.text: Si je m'attache au temps qui court
lines.translation: If I focus on the time that is passing
lines.grammar: The phrase "au temps qui court" is an idiomatic expression indicating a sense of urgency or fleeting nature, equivalent to English "as things stand" or "in the present situation". The verb "attache" is in the present tense, emphasizing the speaker's current focus.

lines.text: Si demain m'appelait au secours
lines.translation: If tomorrow he called me for help
lines.grammar: The phrase "demain" is used to express a hypothetical or uncertain future, equivalent to the English expression "if tomorrow".

lines.text: Si mon cœur devient même lourd pour toi
lines.translation: If my heart even becomes heavy for you
lines.grammar: The phrase "devient même" is an idiomatic expression indicating a hypothetical or potential situation, rather than a literal prediction. The use of the present tense "devient" implies a future possibility or consequence.

lines.text: Je resterai pour toujours
lines.translation: I will stay forever
lines.grammar: The phrase "je resterai" is in the future tense, indicating a commitment or promise to stay. The idiomatic expression "pour toujours" means "forever" and emphasizes the duration of staying.

lines.text: L'horloge tourne autour de moi
lines.translation: The clock revolves around me
lines.grammar: This idiomatic expression uses the present continuous tense (tourne) to convey a sense of circular motion, emphasizing the clock's constant movement around the speaker.

lines.text: Tout est rose autour de toi
lines.translation: Everything is rosy around you
lines.grammar: The phrase "Tout est rose" is an idiomatic expression that conveys a sense of everything being fine or going well, using the metaphorical concept of roses to describe a pleasant situation.

lines.text: Les étoiles défilent autour de nous
lines.translation: The stars are passing around us
lines.grammar: This sentence uses the present continuous tense to convey a sense of ongoing action, emphasizing the dynamic movement of the stars. The phrase "autour de nous" is an idiomatic expression meaning "around us".

lines.text: J'suis côté de l'est à l'ouest
lines.translation: I'm on the east coast, on the west coast
lines.grammar: The phrase "J'suis" is an informal way of saying "I am" in French, using the contraction of "je suis". This construction is used to express a sense of movement or action, and is often translated as "I'm" in English.

lines.text: Sur tes qualités, je peux compter
lines.translation: I can count on your qualities.
lines.grammar: This idiomatic expression uses the present tense to convey a sense of reliability and trustworthiness, implying that the speaker has confidence in the person's abilities.

lines.text: Jamais j'retournerai ma veste
lines.translation: I will never change my tune
lines.grammar: The phrase "j'returnerai" is a future negation of the verb "retourner", emphasizing the speaker's determination to maintain their stance, similar to the English idiom "I'll never back down".

lines.text: Ma vie, j'veux la passer à t'écouter

lines.grammar: The phrase "j'veux" is an informal way of saying "I want" in the present tense, using the contraction of "je veux". This construction is commonly used in spoken French and is equivalent to the formal "Je veux" in written or more formal contexts.

lines.text: J'te lirai matin et soir, s'il le faut
lines.translation: I'll read to you morning and night, if necessary.
lines.grammar: The phrase "J'te" is a informal way of saying "I'll tell you" or "I'll let you know", using the informal "tu" form and the contraction "j'" instead of "je".

lines.text: Et même jusqu'à tard, s'il le faut (eh-eh)
lines.translation: And even until late, if necessary (eh-eh)
lines.grammar: The phrase "s'il le faut" is an idiomatic expression meaning "if necessary", used to emphasize the speaker's willingness to do something. The verb "faut" is in the subjunctive mood, indicating a hypothetical or uncertain situation.

lines.text: Nan, le temps, le temps ne pourra rien changer
lines.translation: No, time, time won't change anything.
lines.grammar: The phrase "le temps ne pourra" is in the future tense, indicating that no matter what happens in the future, it will not make a difference. The idiom "ne pas pouvoir" means "won't be able to" or "can't".

lines.text: Écrivons toutes nos phrases au pluriel
